text: 3. What is the most important thing that you learned while working on TDS?
Keeping our publication simple is essential to fulfilling our mission of sharing concepts, ideas, and codes.

TDS grew so much, so quickly, that it could have been very easy for us to forget our initial mission. We could have tried to do too much or to focus on superficial things. Keeping our publication simple enables us to focus on what is essential, which is what our audience and contributors want us to do.
But keeping TDS simple isnâ€™t as easy as it seems.

We continually have to remind ourselves of why weâ€™re doing what we are doing. We donâ€™t want to rush into anything just because itâ€™s new and shiny. Weâ€™re learning to be patient. In building something like TDS, being patient is much more vital than I ever would have believed.
2. How can I convince my manager to invest in data science?
Try to demonstrate clearly what business value your data science projects would bring to the company.
Your manager will always challenge your ideas, and thatâ€™s why you need to be prepared.
If you can make the case that your data science projects will bring critical business value while being reasonably feasible, your manager will have fewer reasons to refuse them!

Start by plotting all your potential data science projects on a simple graph and discuss them with your team. Your goal is to be creative enough to find projects that are both valuable and achievable.
